ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Developed better Chinese reading, writing, and speaking abilities.
Improved my Chinese (reading, writing, and cultural knowledge)
Speaking, reading, writing skills in Chinese.
I was able to significantly expand my vocabulary, build my understanding of Chinese grammar, and learn about Chinese society.
i learned more chinese vocabulary and more phrases in chinese.
Had meaningful discussions about Chinese culture and learned the vocab to do so.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: the course was structured to be very interactive and engaging, with a good mix of reading and recording homework assignments, presentations, and group projects. Also, Zhang Laoshi is absolutely amazing; he is very kind and knows a ton about Chinese culture and history.
Weaknesses: none, besides the online format this semester
I really enjoyed the readings and the writing assignments!

The strengths of this course lies in the structure of the course, that is, that they understand language is improved through constant repetition and frequent use; as a result, the not too heavy workload but very routine homework assignments is very effective.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think this course was fairly well adapted to the online format, with online assessments, Zoom breakout room discussions, and virtual class discussions. There wasn't much that could be improved in this respect.
I had a high level of engagement in this class, in class discussions also made everything very interesting.

I think this course was effective during covid. Because of the nature of the course during covid, perhaps students were less attentive and there were fewer opportunities for students to practice on the spot without preparation on hand, but from the course administration's point of view, I think they did all that they could have

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Definitely, this course allowed me to reconnect with my Chinese language roots after a few years of not really using Chinese. The textbook provides a lot of useful Chinese vocabulary and grammar constructions that will be useful in real life and professional settings, and the essays are a great way to develop the ability to present a cohesive argument in Chinese. Besides, Zhang Laoshi is very knowledgeable and really dedicated to helping his students level up in their Chinese abilities.

I would recommend this course to another student. I would make sure that they are confident about their placement, however, as I was not so sure I was ready for this course and so I did find it rather difficult but if you try very hard and work on all the assignments with diligence, you should be fine.
yes. it was really fun and helped improve my chinese by a lot. workload isnt unreasonable and teachers are very understanding with extensions

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
